clinical_study.brief_title: Fluid Agitation Microbiologic Yield In Pleural Infection Feasibility Study
clinical_study.official_title: Pleural Fluid Agitation For Improving The Microbiologic Diagnostic Yield In Pleural Infection - A Comparative Feasibility Study

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to compare the microbiologic diagnostic yield of pre-aspiration agitated pleural fluid versus that of conventionally aspirated fluid in pleural infection patients. The main question it aims to answer is, whether fluid agitation helps to increase the microbiological yield.

detailed_description.textblock: In pleural infection, It is suggested that the bacteria being diagnostically targeted, might more likely be residing on the pleural surface with a better blood supply and nutrition rather than being planktonic in the acidic, glucose deficient pleural fluid. The investigators thus hypothesize that an agitation of the pleural fluid prior to sample aspiration would aid in achieving a better cellular representation of the pleural space. This could have the effect of washing bacterial cells off the pleural surface as well as moving sedimented cells in the aspirated sample. This study aims to investigate whether an increase in the microbiological yield for infected pleural fluid could be achieved by a pre-aspiration agitation of the pleural fluid which would have a positive effect on management and eventual patient outcomes. Adult participants with pleural infection will undergo thoracentesis via both the standard and agitated fluid techniques guided by thoracic ultrasound. Microbiological yields will be compared.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All participants will undergo both thoracentesis techniques; the standard and the experimental pre-aspiration agitated fluid techniques
study_design_info.masking_description: Laboratory personnel responsible for the microbiological and biochemical analysis will be blinded to the identity of the paired samples.

primary_outcome.measure: Diagnostic yield of the microbiologic analysis
primary_outcome.description: Percentage of samples with a positive microbiologic result among both aspiration techniques

secondary_outcome.measure: LDH level difference between both aspiration methods
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in LDH levels in the aspirated fluid via both techniques

secondary_outcome.measure: Glucose level difference between both aspiration methods
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in glucose levels in the aspirated fluid via both techniques

secondary_outcome.measure: Protein level difference between both aspiration methods
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in protein levels in the aspirated fluid via both techniques

secondary_outcome.measure: Neutrophilic count difference between both aspiration methods
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in neutrophilic count in the aspirated fluid via both techniques

secondary_outcome.measure: Lymphocytic count difference between both aspiration methods
secondary_outcome.description: Difference in lymphocytic count in the aspirated fluid via both techniques

arm_group.arm_group_label: Standard thoracentesis followed by pre-aspiration fluid agitation
arm_group.description: Participants will undergo the standard thoracentesis followed by the experimental pre-aspiration fluid agitation technique

intervention.description: Using a 16-18 gauge cannula, a standard thoracentesis will be performed then a sample of pleural fluid will be aspirated and rapidly flushed into the pleural space and redrawn again for a few cycles before a sample is finally drawn into the collection syringe
intervention.arm_group_label: Standard thoracentesis followed by pre-aspiration fluid agitation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age >18 years old
2. Pleural infection based on clinical presentation, imaging or laboratory investigations and pleural fluid examination showing glucose < 40 mg/dL or pH <7.2 with lower respiratory infection or pus on aspiration
3. At least a moderate amount of pleural fluid collection (2 or more intercostal spaces on thoracic ultrasound)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Minimal - mild pleural fluid deemed unsuitable for aspiration and agitation
2. Hemodynamic instability
3. Uncorrected coagulopathy
4. Transudative or exudative lymphocytic pleural effusion on biochemical analysis
